elements.content: Three air-stable Co­(II) mononuclear complexes with different aromatic substituents have been prepared and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The mononuclear complexes [Co­(H2L1)2]·2THF (1), [Co­(HL2)2] (2), and [Co­(H2L3)2]·CH2Cl2 (3) (where H3L1, H2L2, and H3L3 represent 3-hydroxy-naphthalene-2-carboxylic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, nicotinic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, and 2-hydroxy-benzoic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, respectively) feature a distorted mer octahedral coordination geometry. Detailed magnetic studies of 1–3 have been conducted using direct and alternating current magnetic susceptibility data. Field-induced slow magnetic relaxation was observed for these three complexes. There are few examples of such behavior in (distorted) octahedral coordination geometry (OC) Co­(II) mononuclear complexes with uniaxial anisotropy. Analysis of the six-coordinate Co­(II) mononuclear single-ion magnets (SIMs) in the literature using the SHAPE program revealed that they all show what is best described as distorted trigonal prismatic (TRP) coordination geometry, and in general, these show negative D zero-field splitting (ZFS) values. On the other hand, all the Co­(II) mononuclear complexes displaying what is best approximated as distorted octahedral (OC) coordination geometry show positive D values. In the new Co­(II) mononuclear complexes we describe here, there is an ambiguity, since the rigid tridentate ligands confer what is best described for an octahedral complex as a mer coordination geometry, but the actual shape of the first coordination sphere is between octahedral and trigonal prismatic. The negative D values observed experimentally and supported by high-level electronic structure calculations are thus in line with a trigonal prismatic geometry. However, a consideration of the rhombicity as indicated by the E value of the ZFS in conjunction with the SHAPE analysis shows that in this case it is difficult to distinguish between the OC and TRP descriptions.

elements.content: Three mononuclear Co­(II) single-ion magnets are presented. Significant distortion away from octahedral geometry toward trigonal prismatic, in spite of the mer coordination of the ligands, explains the observation of negative uniaxial anisotropy D values.
elements.clean_text: Three mononuclear Co(II) single-ion magnets are presented. Significant distortion away from octahedral geometry toward trigonal prismatic, in spite of the mer coordination of the ligands, explains the observation of negative uniaxial anisotropy D values.

elements.content: Since Ishikawa et al. reported the first lanthanide ion based single-ion magnet (SIM), TbIII(Pc)2, many mononuclear lanthanide and some actinide-based compounds have been reported to exhibit slow magnetic relaxation. More recently, considerable efforts have been extended to the research of SIMs with 3d metal centers (3d-SIMs), including Fe­(I, II, III), Co­(I, II), Mn­(III, IV), Ni­(I, II), Re­(IV), Cu­(II), and V­(III). With the development of this research area, it is now suggested that mononuclear 3d metal compounds showing slow magnetic relaxation require a low coordination number which leads to a relatively weak ligand field, thus reducing the 3d orbital splitting energy, thereby enhancing the magnetic anisotropy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since Ishikawa et al. reported the first lanthanide ion based single-ion magnet (SIM), TbIII(Pc)2, many mononuclear lanthanide and some actinide-based compounds have been reported to exhibit slow magnetic relaxation. More recently, considerable efforts have been extended to the research of SIMs with 3d metal centers (3d-SIMs), including Fe(I, II, III), Co(I, II), Mn(III, IV), Ni(I, II), Re(IV), Cu(II), and V(III). With the development of this research area, it is now suggested that mononuclear 3d metal compounds showing slow magnetic relaxation require a low coordination number which leads to a relatively weak ligand field, thus reducing the 3d orbital splitting energy, thereby enhancing the magnetic anisotropy.

elements.content: According to experimental and theoretical studies, six-coordinated Co­(II) mononuclear complexes with trigonal prismatic and octahedral coordination geometry are good candidates for SIMs. The origin for that is first-order spin–orbit coupling in the ground state of Co­(II) in these coordination symmetries. In the case of distorted geometries, the lowest states can often be described by a quartet state with zero-field splitting (ZFS). Supported by magnetization measurements and ab initio calculations, the value of the axial ZFS parameter D for distorted octahedral coordination geometries of mononuclear Co­(II) compounds is usually expected to be positive, but theoretically could also be negative. Up to now there are few Co­(II) mononuclear complexes known where D is negative and where slow magnetic relaxation, even with applied dc fields, is observed.

In the case of distorted geometries, the lowest states can often be described by a quartet state with zero-field splitting (ZFS). Supported by magnetization measurements and ab initio calculations, the value of the axial ZFS parameter D for distorted octahedral coordination geometries of mononuclear Co(II) compounds is usually expected to be positive, but theoretically could also be negative. Up to now there are few Co(II) mononuclear complexes known where D is negative and where slow magnetic relaxation, even with applied dc fields, is observed.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis, structures, magnetic properties, and electronic states of three Co­(II) complexes: [Co­(H2L1)2]·2THF (1), [Co­(HL2)2] (2), and [Co­(H2L3)2]·CH2Cl2 (3) (where H3L1, H2L2, and H3L3 represent 3-hydroxy-naphthalene-2-carboxylic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, nicotinic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, and 2-hydroxy-benzoic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, respectively). All of them are field-induced SIMs with negative D parameters and nonvanishing rhombicity.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis, structures, magnetic properties, and electronic states of three Co(II) complexes: [Co(H2L1)2]⋅2THF (1), [Co(HL2)2] (2), and [Co(H2L3)2]⋅CH2Cl2 (3) (where H3L1, H2L2, and H3L3 represent 3-hydroxy-naphthalene-2-carboxylic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, nicotinic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, and 2-hydroxy-benzoic acid (6-hydroxymethyl-pyridin-2-ylmethylene) hydrazide, respectively). All of them are field-induced SIMs with negative D parameters and nonvanishing rhombicity.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out using an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. Fourier transform IR spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were measured on a PerkinElmer Spectrum GX spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr discs. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out on a STOE STADI-P diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation with λ = 1.5406 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

General Information

All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out using an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. Fourier transform IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were measured on a PerkinElmer Spectrum GX spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr discs. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out on a STOE STADI-P diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation with λ = 1.5406 Å.

elements.content: A solution of 6-hydroxymethyl-pyridine-2-carbaldehyde (27.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 3-hydroxy-naphthalene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide (40.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) in 5 mL of MeOH and 10 mL of MeCN was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, then Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred for an additional 5 min before NaOAc·2.5H2O (68 mg, 0.5 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was added. The resulting mixture was filtered. The pale red color solution was left undisturbed, and after 1 week microcrystalline material had precipitated. This was dissolved in mixture of 15 mL of THF/MeOH in a 2:1 ratio. Slow evaporation in air produced red needle crystals of 1 in 90% yield. Anal. Calcd (found) (%) for CoC36H28N6O6·2THF·MeOH: C, 61.71 (61.99); H, 5.52 (5.28); N, 9.60 (9.86). Selected IR data (KBr, cm–1) for 1: 3455­(br), 3053­(w), 1633­(m), 1563­(m), 1507(s), 1444­(m), 1353(s), 1329(s), 1300(s), 1237(s), 1147­(m), 1112(s), 1069(s), 1004­(w), 951­(w), 910­(w), 835­(m), 793(s), 733(s), 658­(m), 621­(m), 473(s).

elements.content: Data for 1–3 were measured at 150 K on a STOE IPDS II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystals of 4 were of poor quality and weakly diffracting, and data were measured at the ANKA synchrotron source, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, using silicon-monochromated radiation of wavelength 0.79927 Å. Structures were solved with SHELXT, and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 using SHELXL-2014 or SHELXL-2016.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structures

Data for 1-3 were measured at 150 K on a STOE IPDS II diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystals of 4 were of poor quality and weakly diffracting, and data were measured at the ANKA synchrotron source, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, using silicon-monochromated radiation of wavelength 0.79927 Å. Structures were solved with SHELXT, and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 using SHELXL-2014 or SHELXL-2016.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were obtained using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer MPMS-XL in the temperature range of 1.8–300 K. Measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples constrained in eicosane. Magnetization isotherms were collected at 2, 3, 5 K between 0 and 7 T. Alternating current (ac) susceptibility measurements were performed with an oscillating field of 3 Oe and ac frequencies ranging from 1 to 1500 Hz (31 steps). The magnetic data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contribution.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

The magnetic susceptibility measurements were obtained using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer MPMS-XL in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K. Measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples constrained in eicosane. Magnetization isotherms were collected at 2, 3, 5 K between 0 and 7 T. Alternating current (ac) susceptibility measurements were performed with an oscillating field of 3 Oe and ac frequencies ranging from 1 to 1500 Hz (31 steps). The magnetic data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contribution.

elements.content: We performed quantum chemical calculations based on the X-ray structures of the complexes. In the first step, the positions of the hydrogen atoms were optimized at DFT level (BP86/m3/def2-SVP) applying the program package TURBOMOLE. On the basis of these geometries, the electronic structure and the low-lying electronic states were obtained in a similar way as reported in ref . In all the following calculations the basis sets on Co and the O and N atoms of its first coordination sphere were enlarged to def2-TZVPP. In the first step, state average CASSCF calculations were performed considering all configurations with seven electrons in the five 3d orbitals CASSCF­(7,5). The orbitals were optimized for an average including all 10 quartet states equally weighted. With this choice all 3d orbitals are optimized simultaneously without any bias. Dynamic correlation was considered for the lowest seven quartet states within the multiconfiguration coupled electron-pair approach (MCCEPA). Spin–orbit coupling was calculated considering all determinants of the CASSCF­(7,5) active space using the scaled nucleus approach with a scaling factor of 0.61 for the one-electron spin–orbit integrals. In the spin–orbit configuration interaction (SOCI) calculations, dynamic correlation was included by shifting the lowest seven CASSCF states to E cor(I) – 1/7Σ I (E cor(I) – E cas(I)) (SOCI*). For all complexes, the first two Kramers doublets are well-separated from all other states. This makes it possible to analyze the zero-field tensor for a pseudospin of S = 3/2 using effective Hamiltonian theory. The g-tensors for the first two Kramers doublets were obtained from the Zeeman integrals assuming a pseudospin of 1/2 for each of the Kramers doublets. For the calculation of the magnetization and the magnetic susceptibility data, the energies of the first six Kramers doublets with and without magnetic field along the magnetic main axes coinciding with the Cartesian axes (shown in Figure S13, Supporting Information) were used to evaluate energy derivatives and partition functions numerically.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculations

We performed quantum chemical calculations based on the X-ray structures of the complexes. In the first step, the positions of the hydrogen atoms were optimized at DFT level (BP86/m3/def2-SVP) applying the program package TURBOMOLE. On the basis of these geometries, the electronic structure and the low-lying electronic states were obtained in a similar way as reported in ref . In all the following calculations the basis sets on Co and the O and N atoms of its first coordination sphere were enlarged to def2-TZVPP. In the first step, state average CASSCF calculations were performed considering all configurations with seven electrons in the five 3d orbitals CASSCF(7,5). The orbitals were optimized for an average including all 10 quartet states equally weighted. With this choice all 3d orbitals are optimized simultaneously without any bias. Dynamic correlation was considered for the lowest seven quartet states within the multiconfiguration coupled electron-pair approach (MCCEPA). Spin-orbit coupling was calculated considering all determinants of the CASSCF(7,5) active space using the scaled nucleus approach with a scaling factor of 0.61 for the one-electron spin-orbit integrals. In the spin-orbit configuration interaction (SOCI) calculations, dynamic correlation was included by shifting the lowest seven CASSCF states to E cor(I) - 1/7Σ I (E cor(I) - E cas(I)) (SOCI*). For all complexes, the first two Kramers doublets are well-separated from all other states. This makes it possible to analyze the zero-field tensor for a pseudospin of S = 3/2 using effective Hamiltonian theory. The g-tensors for the first two Kramers doublets were obtained from the Zeeman integrals assuming a pseudospin of 1/2 for each of the Kramers doublets. For the calculation of the magnetization and the magnetic susceptibility data, the energies of the first six Kramers doublets with and without magnetic field along the magnetic main axes coinciding with the Cartesian axes (shown in Figure S13, Supporting Information) were used to evaluate energy derivatives and partition functions numerically.

elements.content: Crystallographic data of complexes 1–4 are listed in , and selected bond lengths (Ångstroms) and angles of compounds 1–4 are summarized in . The purity of compounds 1–3 was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S1) and elemental analysis. The structures of 1–3 are presented in . They display similar coordination environments with the only difference for the complexes lying in the nature of the aromatic groups of the tridentate ligands. Two perpendicular monodeprotonated ligands displaying a η0:η1:η1:η1:η0 () coordination mode chelate the CoII ions to form neutral [Co­(L)2] complexes. The CoII ions display a distorted six-coordinate CoN4O2 environment with donor atoms from the two rigid ligands. If we regard the coordination geometry as distorted octahedral, then as a result of the rigidity of the ligand, a mer () coordination geometry must be adopted, and no facial coordination mode is possible. The bite of the ligands means that it is not possible to achieve idealized octahedral (OC) coordination geometry. Furthermore, it seems that the system is trying to distort toward trigonal prismatic (TRP) coordination geometry as revealed from the results of the SHAPE analysis. The calculated values from this analysis were found to be 5.54, 5.91, and 4.99 for the OC polyhedron and 7.10, 6.56, and 7.82 for the TRP polyhedron for compounds 1–3, respectively. In other words, the Co­(II) coordination spheres correspond to a situation along the OC ↔ TRP deformation pathway, but are slightly closer to OC coordination geometry, which is to be expected.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Analysis

Crystallographic data of complexes 1-4 are listed in , and selected bond lengths (Ångstroms) and angles of compounds 1-4 are summarized in . The purity of compounds 1-3 was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (Figure S1) and elemental analysis. The structures of 1-3 are presented in . They display similar coordination environments with the only difference for the complexes lying in the nature of the aromatic groups of the tridentate ligands. Two perpendicular monodeprotonated ligands displaying a η0:η1:η1:η1:η0 () coordination mode chelate the CoII ions to form neutral [Co(L)2] complexes. The CoII ions display a distorted six-coordinate CoN4O2 environment with donor atoms from the two rigid ligands. If we regard the coordination geometry as distorted octahedral, then as a result of the rigidity of the ligand, a mer () coordination geometry must be adopted, and no facial coordination mode is possible. The bite of the ligands means that it is not possible to achieve idealized octahedral (OC) coordination geometry. Furthermore, it seems that the system is trying to distort toward trigonal prismatic (TRP) coordination geometry as revealed from the results of the SHAPE analysis. The calculated values from this analysis were found to be 5.54, 5.91, and 4.99 for the OC polyhedron and 7.10, 6.56, and 7.82 for the TRP polyhedron for compounds 1-3, respectively. In other words, the Co(II) coordination spheres correspond to a situation along the OC ↔ TRP deformation pathway, but are slightly closer to OC coordination geometry, which is to be expected.

elements.content: The angles between the two rigid ligands are 88.095°, 89.472°, and 87.283° for complexes 1–3, respectively, i.e., more or less orthogonal to each other as expected for mer coordination geometry. However, the axial O–Co–N angles (green text) are much smaller than the 180° expected for idealized octahedral geometry (). Also, the Oaxis–Co–Oeq or Neq (, red text) and Naxis–Co–Oeq or Neq (, blue text) angles deviate from 90° for idealized octahedral geometry. The Co–Ohydrazone bond distances are shorter than the Co–Npyridine bond distances, which are in turn slightly longer than the Co–Nschiff‑base bond distances in these three compounds, all of which are typical for high-spin CoII ions and in agreement with the result of the SHAPE analysis.

The Co-Ohydrazone bond distances are shorter than the Co-Npyridine bond distances, which are in turn slightly longer than the Co-Nschiff-base bond distances in these three compounds, all of which are typical for high-spin CoII ions and in agreement with the result of the SHAPE analysis.

elements.content: The seeming contradiction of a mer coordination geometry leading to a reasonable description of the system in terms of trigonal prismatic coordination geometry can be explained through closer examination of the coordination spheres of the Co­(II) centers: by choosing, for example, in compound 3, O2, N4, N5 to define one triangle and N1, N2, O5 to define the other, a rather distorted trigonal prism can be identified, as shown in . In this representation it is clear that one of the six donor atoms deviates significantly from its expected position on the trigonal prism.

elements.content: The mononuclear units are well-isolated from each other, the shortest intermolecular Co–Co distances being 8.358(17), 7.922(8), and 6.249(13) Å for 1–3, respectively. Additionally, there are intramolecular hydrogen bonds in compound 1, and intermolecular hydrogen bonds in compound 2. No other interactions were found in these two compounds, whereas for 3, there are not only intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds, but also short π–π interactions of 4.04 Å were found (Figure S2, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The mononuclear units are well-isolated from each other, the shortest intermolecular Co-Co distances being 8.358(17), 7.922(8), and 6.249(13) Å for 1-3, respectively. Additionally, there are intramolecular hydrogen bonds in compound 1, and intermolecular hydrogen bonds in compound 2. No other interactions were found in these two compounds, whereas for 3, there are not only intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds, but also short π-π interactions of 4.04 Å were found (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were performed on samples of crushed single crystals at 1000 Oe over the temperature range 1.8–300 K. The data are summarized in . The dc magnetic susceptibility data () revealed that the room-temperature χT values for 1–3 are 2.31, 2.58, and 2.65 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are significantly higher than the expected value of 1.875 cm3 K mol–1 for one isolated CoII ion (S = 3/2) with g = 2. The values are in the range 2.1–3.4 cm3 K mol–1 for the highly anisotropic CoII ions with a considerable contribution from orbital angular momentum. The χT values for all compounds are roughly constant in the high-temperature range (50–300 K), then drop rapidly to a minimum of 1.60, 2.00, and 2.08 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K for 1–3, respectively. This phenomenon is consistent with a Curie-type behavior for isolated CoII. The decrease at low temperature is possibly due to the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the CoII ions. In a distorted octahedral ligand field, CoII ions typically possess six Kramers doublets in the low-energy range. According to our calculations, the energy difference between the first two Kramers doublets is about 100 K (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Hence, at very low temperatures, each CoII ion may be described by an effective spin S = 1/2 and a Zeeman-type Hamiltonian using highly anisotropic g matrices. In the temperature range of the susceptibility measurements, the lowest two Kramers doublets have to be considered. Therefore, the experimental χT data were fitted using the PHI program assuming an effective spin of S = 3/2, and using the anisotropic Hamiltonian given by H = D ( S z 2 − S ( S + 1 ) / 3 ) + E ( S x 2 − S y 2 ) + μ B S · g · B where μB is the Bohr magneton and D, E, S, B represent the axial and rhombic ZFS parameters, the spin operator, and magnetic field vectors, respectively. In parameters are given for D, E, and an anisotropic g. To investigate the influence of the different parameters, fittings were obtained applying different constraints. The results are summarized in Table S3 and compared to the measured susceptibilities in Figure S14. These data suggest that the magnetic anisotropy is of the Ising type, i.e., the M S = ±3/2 sublevels lie lower in energy than the ±1/2.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Magnetic measurements were performed on samples of crushed single crystals at 1000 Oe over the temperature range  1.8-300 K. The data are summarized in . The dc magnetic susceptibility data () revealed that the room-temperature χT values for 1-3 are 2.31, 2.58, and 2.65 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are significantly higher than the expected value of 1.875 cm3 K mol-1 for one isolated CoII ion (S = 3/2) with g = 2. The values are in the range  2.1-3.4 cm3 K mol-1 for the highly anisotropic CoII ions with a considerable contribution from orbital angular momentum. The χT values for all compounds are roughly constant in the high-temperature range (50-300 K), then drop rapidly to a minimum of 1.60, 2.00, and 2.08 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K for 1-3, respectively. This phenomenon is consistent with a Curie-type behavior for isolated CoII. The decrease at low temperature is possibly due to the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the CoII ions. In a distorted octahedral ligand field, CoII ions typically possess six Kramers doublets in the low-energy range. According to our calculations, the energy difference between the first two Kramers doublets is about 100 K (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Hence, at very low temperatures, each CoII ion may be described by an effective spin S = 1/2 and a Zeeman-type Hamiltonian using highly anisotropic g matrices. In the temperature range of the susceptibility measurements, the lowest two Kramers doublets have to be considered. Therefore, the experimental χT data were fitted using the PHI program assuming an effective spin of S = 3/2, and using the anisotropic Hamiltonian given by    H = D  (     S   z     2   - S  ( S + 1 )  / 3 )  + E  (     S   x     2   -     S   y     2   )  +   μ   B   S ⋅ g ⋅ B   where μB is the Bohr magneton and D, E, S, B represent the axial and rhombic ZFS parameters, the spin operator, and magnetic field vectors, respectively. In  parameters are given for D, E, and an anisotropic g. To investigate the influence of the different parameters, fittings were obtained applying different constraints. The results are summarized in Table S3 and compared to the measured susceptibilities in Figure S14. These data suggest that the magnetic anisotropy is of the Ising type, i.e., the M  S  = ±3/2 sublevels lie lower in energy than the ±1/2.

elements.content: The negative sign of D was also observed in the spin–orbit configuration interaction (SOCI) calculations presented in . However, the large value of the rhombicity indicates that the sign of D may be ambiguous. As in our former work on trigonal prismatic Co­(II) complexes, the lowest two Kramers doublets are described by individual g-tensors in the ab initio calculations. The g-tensor of the lowest Kramers doublet is strongly axial while it is rhombic for the second doublet. This was also observed for the individual g-tensors for the lowest two Kramers doublets obtained from the PHI analysis. Thus, although it is possible to fit the susceptibility data using the assumption E = 0.0 cm–1 and g x = g y , the ab initio calculations point to a significant rhombic distortion in the system.

However, the large value of the rhombicity indicates that the sign of D may be ambiguous. As in our former work on trigonal prismatic Co(II) complexes, the lowest two Kramers doublets are described by individual g-tensors in the ab initio calculations. The g-tensor of the lowest Kramers doublet is strongly axial while it is rhombic for the second doublet. This was also observed for the individual g-tensors for the lowest two Kramers doublets obtained from the PHI analysis. Thus, although it is possible to fit the susceptibility data using the assumption E = 0.0 cm-1 and g  x  = g  y , the ab initio calculations point to a significant rhombic distortion in the system.

elements.content: In Figures S11 and S12 the measured and calculated magnetic susceptibilities and magnetization data are compared. For complexes 2 and 3, the calculated susceptibilities are slightly lower than the measured ones. The same holds true for the calculated magnetizations. This indicates that the calculated magnetic moments are a bit too small compared to the experimentally determined ones.

This indicates that the calculated magnetic moments are a bit too small compared to the experimentally determined ones.

elements.content: The field dependence of the magnetization for the compounds at 2 K is shown in and Figure S3. The magnetization at 7 T reaches 2.73, 2.62, and 2.82 μB for compounds 1–3, respectively. The lack of saturation for the compounds also suggests the presence of magnetic anisotropy. However, the parameter sets obtained from the susceptibility data were not appropriate to describe the magnetization data. For the latter an anisotropic g-factor for S = 3/2 was fitted with fixed values for D and E taken from the susceptibility fit (see Table S4 and Figure S15).

The magnetization at 7 T reaches 2.73, 2.62, and 2.82 μB for compounds 1-3, respectively. The lack of saturation for the compounds also suggests the presence of magnetic anisotropy. However, the parameter sets obtained from the susceptibility data were not appropriate to describe the magnetization data. For the latter an anisotropic g-factor for S = 3/2 was fitted with fixed values for D and E taken from the susceptibility fit (see Table S4 and Figure S15).

elements.content: There is no obvious correlation in terms of variation of the ligand substituent on any of the observed parameters, suggesting that a very fine tuning of the ligand field geometry might be more relevant than electron-withdrawing/donating effects in these systems.
elements.clean_text: There is no obvious correlation in terms of variation of the ligand substituent on any of the observed parameters, suggesting that a very fine tuning of the ligand field geometry might be more relevant than electron-withdrawing/donating effects in these systems.

elements.content: To probe the slow relaxation of the magnetization and quantum tunneling effects within these systems, ac magnetic susceptibilities of 1–3 were investigated in the temperature range of 1.8–20 K. No out-of-phase ac susceptibility (χ″) signals were observed under the zero applied dc field in compounds 1–3 (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The absence of slow relaxation under zero applied dc field is probably due to quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM) which is likely mediated by hyperfine and/or dipolar interactions, since (quadratic) transverse anisotropy cannot mix the wave functions of ±M S level for noninteger spin systems with D < 0 in strictly zero field. The maximum values of the relaxation time under 1000 Oe dc field were obtained by extracting relaxation times from field-dependent ac susceptibilities in an appropriate temperature range (see as well as Figure S5, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: To probe the slow relaxation of the magnetization and quantum tunneling effects within these systems, ac magnetic susceptibilities of 1-3 were investigated in the temperature range of 1.8-20 K. No out-of-phase ac susceptibility (χ") signals were observed under the zero applied dc field in compounds 1-3 (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The absence of slow relaxation under zero applied dc field is probably due to quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM) which is likely mediated by hyperfine and/or dipolar interactions, since (quadratic) transverse anisotropy cannot mix the wave functions of ±M  S  level for noninteger spin systems with D < 0 in strictly zero field. The maximum values of the relaxation time under 1000 Oe dc field were obtained by extracting relaxation times from field-dependent ac susceptibilities in an appropriate temperature range (see  as well as Figure S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: The magnetization relaxation time (τ) was derived from the frequency-dependent measurements and plotted as a function of 1/T in and Figure S7. The τ of each compound shows a strong temperature dependence and is well-described by an Arrhenius law, τ = τ0 exp­(U eff/k B T), characteristic for a thermally activated mechanism involving a barrier U eff for reversal of magnetization. There is only one relaxation process for compounds 1 and 2, and no quantum tunneling regime was observed within this frequency window, implying that the applied field of 1000 Oe is appropriate to suppress QTM effects. The obtained values are τ0 = 8.35 × 10–6 s for the pre-exponential factor and U eff = 7.30 K for the energy barrier of 1, τ0 = 6.13 × 10–6 s and U eff = 10.18 K for 2, while for compound 3, τ0 = 1.16 × 10–5 s and U eff = 14.10 K were found. For compound 3, the thermally activated behavior observed in the high-temperature range is mainly attributed to an Orbach relaxation process through the excited M S = ±1/2 levels. In the low-temperature region, magnetic relaxation is likely dominated by a Raman and/or a direct phonon-based relaxation mechanism. The relaxation times for 3 in 1.8–3.2 K were fitted using a T –n law (), giving n = 3.6. This value is close to those previously reported for six-coordinate CoII mononuclear complexes with negative D (n = 2.2 and 4.3) and in agreement with values for Kramers ions as a result of the presence of optical and acoustic phonons (n = 1–6). Therefore, we also analyzed the temperature dependence of the relaxation time using the expression τ − 1 = C T n + τ 0 − 1 ⁡ exp ( − U / K B T ) + B which allows for Raman, Orbach, and temperature-independent processes. The best fit was obtained with the following parameters: C = 15.4 K–3.6 s–1 for n = 3.6, B = 150 s–1, τ0 = 1.16 × 10–5 s, and spin-reversal barrier U = 14.10 K (), which is almost the same as obtained in the analysis for the separated processes.

This value is close to those previously reported for six-coordinate CoII mononuclear complexes with negative D (n = 2.2 and 4.3) and in agreement with values for Kramers ions as a result of the presence of optical and acoustic phonons (n = 1-6). Therefore, we also analyzed the temperature dependence of the relaxation time using the expression      τ   - 1   = C   T   n   +     τ   0     - 1   ⁡ exp  ( - U /   K   B   T )  + B   which allows for Raman, Orbach, and temperature-independent processes. The best fit was obtained with the following parameters: C = 15.4 K-3.6 s-1 for n = 3.6, B = 150 s-1, τ0 = 1.16 × 10-5 s, and spin-reversal barrier U = 14.10 K (), which is almost the same as obtained in the analysis for the separated processes.

elements.content: To inspect the distribution of the relaxation time, the Cole–Cole plots were scrutinized for compounds 1–3 ( and Figure S8, Supporting Information). The data can be fitted using a generalized Debye model with α < 0.08 for 1, α < 0.16 for 2, and α < 0.12 for 3 where small α values indicate small deviations from the pure Debye model as revealed by a narrow distribution for the major relaxation process for all three compounds (Table S1, Supporting Information). For compounds 1 and 2, the Cole–Cole plots show the onset of a second relaxation process (Figure S8, Supporting Information).

elements.content: In order to better understand the magnetic behavior of these three complexes, a dilution study using isostructural diamagnetic Zn­(II) would be beneficial. However, all attempts to prepare these Zn­(II) analogues were unsuccessful. In the one case where we were able to isolate a compound, which was formed with the ligand H2L2, only a small amount of single crystals was obtained and shown to be an infinite Zn­(II) chain where the Zn­(II) is five-coordinate (see and Figure S16 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: As mentioned above, six-coordinate Co­(II) mononuclear complexes with TRP and OC coordination geometry are good candidates for SIMs. To probe the structure–property relationship, some crucial parameters of the above-mentioned Co­(II) SIMs, including deviations from idealized OC and TRP coordination geometry, zero-field splitting parameters (D), applied field, energy barriers (U eff), and relaxation times (τ0), have been listed in . For TRP coordination geometry Co­(II) SIMs, all show high uniaxial anisotropy and slow magnetic relaxation even in the absence of applied dc fields. The TRP coordination geometry (n-Bu4N)­[CoIICoIII 3(L–NO 2)6] has an energy barrier of 147 K without applied dc field, which is very high for Co­(II) SIMs. These findings are in good agreement with the prediction of Gómez-Coca et al. for TRP coordination geometry Co­(II) SIMs. The OC coordination geometry Co­(II) SIMs always show uniaxial magnetic anisotropy associated with large easy plane anisotropy. According to the SHAPE analysis, all of the previously reported octahedrally coordinated Co­(II) SIMs show positive D values, suggesting only small deviations from idealized OC coordination geometry. On the other hand, the 11 compounds which are well-described as trigonal prismatic all have large negative D values. However, for two previously reported Co­(II) SIMs and complexes 1–3 in this work it is difficult to distinguish between OC and TRP. The fact that the coordination geometry lies between that of octahedral and trigonal prismatic explains the observation of negative, but relatively small, D values compared with the compounds best described as trigonal prismatic. The analysis of the results of the ab initio calculations shows that there are three quartet states at low energies well-separated from all other states for all three complexes (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Because of the distorted ligand field these three states do not show any degeneracy. The energy difference between the lowest two quartet states is in the range of 1000–1500 cm–1 at the MCCEPA level, the third is between 1800 and 2700 cm–1 higher in energy than the ground state, the next states follow at about 6000 cm–1, the lowest doublet state at 14 000 cm–1. It is noted that, for complexes 1–3, the two ligands are rigid, which is ideal for mer coordination geometry in a classic octahedral description. However, the combination of this rigidity with the relatively small bite angles of the ligand leads to a distortion of the octahedral (OC) coordination geometry toward trigonal prismatic (TRP) geometry. This distortion leads to negative D values, which is in line with the perturbation theory based prediction of Gómez-Coca et al. for distortion of OC coordination spheres. It should be stressed here that, only the coordination geometries were considered, whereas the ligand field may also have an important influence on the magnetic properties of the above complexes. In addition, suitable modulation of inter- or intramolecular hydrogen bonds or π–π interactions may also have effects on magnetic relaxation dynamics.
elements.clean_text:
Structure-Property Relationship

As mentioned above, six-coordinate Co(II) mononuclear complexes with TRP and OC coordination geometry are good candidates for SIMs. To probe the structure-property relationship, some crucial parameters of the above-mentioned Co(II) SIMs, including deviations from idealized OC and TRP coordination geometry, zero-field splitting parameters (D), applied field, energy barriers (U eff), and relaxation times (τ0), have been listed in . For TRP coordination geometry Co(II) SIMs, all show high uniaxial anisotropy and slow magnetic relaxation even in the absence of applied dc fields. The TRP coordination geometry (n-Bu4N)[CoIICoIII 3(L-NO 2)6] has an energy barrier of 147 K without applied dc field, which is very high for Co(II) SIMs. These findings are in good agreement with the prediction of Gómez-Coca et al. for TRP coordination geometry Co(II) SIMs. The OC coordination geometry Co(II) SIMs always show uniaxial magnetic anisotropy associated with large easy plane  anisotropy. According to the SHAPE analysis, all of the previously reported octahedrally coordinated Co(II) SIMs show positive D values, suggesting only small deviations from idealized OC coordination geometry. On the other hand, the 11 compounds which are well-described as trigonal prismatic all have large negative D values. However, for two previously reported Co(II) SIMs and complexes 1-3 in this work it is difficult to distinguish between OC and TRP. The fact that the coordination geometry lies between that of octahedral and trigonal prismatic explains the observation of negative, but relatively small, D values compared with the compounds best described as trigonal prismatic. The analysis of the results of the ab initio calculations shows that there are three quartet states at low energies well-separated from all other states for all three complexes (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Because of the distorted ligand field these three states do not show any degeneracy. The energy difference between the lowest two quartet states is in the range of 1000-1500 cm-1 at the MCCEPA level, the third is between 1800 and 2700 cm-1 higher in energy than the ground state, the next states follow at about 6000 cm-1, the lowest doublet state at 14000 cm-1. It is noted that, for complexes 1-3, the two ligands are rigid, which is ideal for mer coordination geometry in a classic octahedral description. However, the combination of this rigidity with the relatively small bite angles of the ligand leads to a distortion of the octahedral (OC) coordination geometry toward trigonal prismatic (TRP) geometry. This distortion leads to negative D values, which is in line with the perturbation theory based prediction of Gómez-Coca et al. for distortion of OC coordination spheres. It should be stressed here that, only the coordination geometries were considered, whereas the ligand field may also have an important influence on the magnetic properties of the above complexes. In addition, suitable modulation of inter- or intramolecular hydrogen bonds or π-π interactions may also have effects on magnetic relaxation dynamics.

elements.content:
Compilation of Six-Coordinated Mononuclear Co­(II) SIMs in Terms of the SHAPE Description of the Coordination Geometry as OC or TRP<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl4-fn1"></xref>

The parameters highlighted as blue text indicate the best descriptions.

In conclusion, we have probed SIM behavior in three air-stable mer coordination geometry mononuclear Co­(II) compounds. All of the compounds exhibit significant anisotropy, and slow magnetic relaxation behavior has been observed under an applied dc field. The observation of negative D parameters in these systems can be explained by the significant distortion away from octahedral coordination toward trigonal prismatic geometry. The subtle difference within the aromatic substituent groups leads to slight variations in the magnetic anisotropy, ZFS parameters, and energy barriers, but without any clear correlation. Further investigation into the variation of the ligand substituents, coordination number, and coordination geometry is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have probed SIM behavior in three air-stable mer coordination geometry mononuclear Co(II) compounds. All of the compounds exhibit significant anisotropy, and slow magnetic relaxation behavior has been observed under an applied dc field. The observation of negative D parameters in these systems can be explained by the significant distortion away from octahedral coordination toward trigonal prismatic geometry. The subtle difference within the aromatic substituent groups leads to slight variations in the magnetic anisotropy, ZFS parameters, and energy barriers, but without any clear correlation. Further investigation into the variation of the ligand substituents, coordination number, and coordination geometry is in progress.

A solution of 6-hydroxymethyl-pyridine-2-carbaldehyde (27.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) and 3-hydroxy-naphthalene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide (40.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) in 5 mL of MeOH and 10 mL of MeCN was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, then Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred for an additional 5 min before NaOAc·2.5H2O (68 mg, 0.5 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was added. The resulting mixture was filtered. The pale red color solution was left undisturbed, and after 1 week microcrystalline material had precipitated. This was dissolved in mixture of 15 mL of THF/MeOH in a 2:1 ratio. Slow evaporation in air produced red needle crystals of 1 in 90% yield. Anal. Calcd (found) (%) for CoC36H28N6O6·2THF·MeOH: C, 61.71 (61.99); H, 5.52 (5.28); N, 9.60 (9.86). Selected IR data (KBr, cm–1) for 1: 3455­(br), 3053­(w), 1633­(m), 1563­(m), 1507(s), 1444­(m), 1353(s), 1329(s), 1300(s), 1237(s), 1147­(m), 1112(s), 1069(s), 1004­(w), 951­(w), 910­(w), 835­(m), 793(s), 733(s), 658­(m), 621­(m), 473(s).

cln_elements.content: Magnetic measurements were performed on samples of crushed single crystals at 1000 Oe over the temperature range 1.8–300 K. The data are summarized in . The dc magnetic susceptibility data () revealed that the room-temperature χT values for 1–3 are 2.31, 2.58, and 2.65 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are significantly higher than the expected value of 1.875 cm3 K mol–1 for one isolated CoII ion (S = 3/2) with g = 2. The values are in the range 2.1–3.4 cm3 K mol–1 for the highly anisotropic CoII ions with a considerable contribution from orbital angular momentum. The χT values for all compounds are roughly constant in the high-temperature range (50–300 K), then drop rapidly to a minimum of 1.60, 2.00, and 2.08 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K for 1–3, respectively. This phenomenon is consistent with a Curie-type behavior for isolated CoII. The decrease at low temperature is possibly due to the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the CoII ions. In a distorted octahedral ligand field, CoII ions typically possess six Kramers doublets in the low-energy range. According to our calculations, the energy difference between the first two Kramers doublets is about 100 K (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Hence, at very low temperatures, each CoII ion may be described by an effective spin S = 1/2 and a Zeeman-type Hamiltonian using highly anisotropic g matrices. In the temperature range of the susceptibility measurements, the lowest two Kramers doublets have to be considered. Therefore, the experimental χT data were fitted using the PHI program assuming an effective spin of S = 3/2, and using the anisotropic Hamiltonian given by H = D ( S z 2 − S ( S + 1 ) / 3 ) + E ( S x 2 − S y 2 ) + μ B S · g · B where μB is the Bohr magneton and D, E, S, B represent the axial and rhombic ZFS parameters, the spin operator, and magnetic field vectors, respectively. In parameters are given for D, E, and an anisotropic g. To investigate the influence of the different parameters, fittings were obtained applying different constraints. The results are summarized in Table S3 and compared to the measured susceptibilities in Figure S14. These data suggest that the magnetic anisotropy is of the Ising type, i.e., the M S = ±3/2 sublevels lie lower in energy than the ±1/2.

Magnetic Properties

Magnetic measurements were performed on samples of crushed single crystals at 1000 Oe over the temperature range  1.8-300 K. The data are summarized in . The dc magnetic susceptibility data () revealed that the room-temperature χT values for 1-3 are 2.31, 2.58, and 2.65 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are significantly higher than the expected value of 1.875 cm3 K mol-1 for one isolated CoII ion (S = 3/2) with g = 2. The values are in the range  2.1-3.4 cm3 K mol-1 for the highly anisotropic CoII ions with a considerable contribution from orbital angular momentum. The χT values for all compounds are roughly constant in the high-temperature range (50-300 K), then drop rapidly to a minimum of 1.60, 2.00, and 2.08 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K for 1-3, respectively. This phenomenon is consistent with a Curie-type behavior for isolated CoII. The decrease at low temperature is possibly due to the intrinsic magnetic anisotropy of the CoII ions. In a distorted octahedral ligand field, CoII ions typically possess six Kramers doublets in the low-energy range. According to our calculations, the energy difference between the first two Kramers doublets is about 100 K (see Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Hence, at very low temperatures, each CoII ion may be described by an effective spin S = 1/2 and a Zeeman-type Hamiltonian using highly anisotropic g matrices. In the temperature range of the susceptibility measurements, the lowest two Kramers doublets have to be considered. Therefore, the experimental χT data were fitted using the PHI program assuming an effective spin of S = 3/2, and using the anisotropic Hamiltonian given by    H = D  (     S   z     2   - S  ( S + 1 )  / 3 )  + E  (     S   x     2   -     S   y     2   )  +   μ   B   S ⋅ g ⋅ B   where μB is the Bohr magneton and D, E, S, B represent the axial and rhombic ZFS parameters, the spin operator, and magnetic field vectors, respectively. In  parameters are given for D, E, and an anisotropic g. To investigate the influence of the different parameters, fittings were obtained applying different constraints. The results are summarized in Table S3 and compared to the measured susceptibilities in Figure S14. These data suggest that the magnetic anisotropy is of the Ising type, i.e., the M  S  = ±3/2 sublevels lie lower in energy than the ±1/2.

ΔE SOC (cm–1) is the energy difference of the two lowest Kramers doublets.

Compilation of Six-Coordinated Mononuclear Co­(II) SIMs in Terms of the SHAPE Description of the Coordination Geometry as OC or TRP<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl4-fn1"></xref>

The parameters highlighted as blue text indicate the best descriptions.

Synthetic scheme and structures of 1, 2, and 3 (top). The lower pictures show the distorted octahedral (OC in SHAPE) description in terms of the mer coordination geometry seen for complexes 1–3 with the rigid ligand backbone shown in green. The coordination bonds and the distorted octahedral coordination geometry in dashed red lines are shown in pale blue on the left. On the right the distorted trigonal prismatic (TRP in SHAPE) representation is illustrated with the prism defined by the purple lines.
